stem: The patient is exhibiting several new deficits. Based on the information in the chart, indicate the most appropriate interdisciplinary referral for each finding.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: **07:00** Patient c/o increased difficulty swallowing thin liquids this morning. No coughing noted during or immediately after swallowing, but voice sounds slightly wet. **09:00** Observed patient struggling to manipulate utensils during breakfast. Dropped spoon several times. Grip strength appears diminished in right hand. **11:00** Patient attempting to communicate needs but having difficulty finding the right words. Speech is slurred and effortful. Understands simple commands but struggles with complex instructions. **13:00** Patient reports feeling increasingly unsteady when walking. States, 'My legs feel like jelly.' Assisted with ambulation to the bathroom. Noted shuffling gait and decreased balance. **15:00** Family at bedside reports patient's increasing social isolation since admission. Patient refuses to participate in group activities and expresses feelings of hopelessness. Family concerned about patient's emotional well-being and adjustment to the hospital environment. **17:00** Noted patient attempting to write a letter to family, but handwriting is very shaky and almost illegible. Patient expresses frustration with inability to perform simple tasks.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Patient appears weak and fatigued. Neuro: Cranial nerves II-XII grossly intact, except for mild facial droop on the right side. Dysarthria noted. Strength 4/5 in right upper and lower extremities. Coordination impaired in right hand. Swallowing: Difficulty with thin liquids. Musculoskeletal: Decreased balance and shuffling gait noted.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content: - Monitor swallowing function. - Assess speech clarity. - Evaluate fine motor skills. - Monitor gait and balance. - Address patient's social isolation.

rows.text: Impaired fine motor skills and grip strength in right hand
Slurred speech and difficulty finding words
Increasing social isolation and feelings of hopelessness

rationale.correct: The correct answers align the patient's specific deficits with the appropriate healthcare professionals. Speech therapists address swallowing and speech issues. Occupational therapists focus on fine motor skills and activities of daily living. Physical therapists work on mobility and balance. Social workers address psychosocial needs and support systems.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect selections misattribute patient needs to the wrong professional discipline. For example, assigning swallowing difficulties to a physical therapist or social isolation to an occupational therapist would be incorrect.

answerBreakdown.rationale: Speech therapists specialize in evaluating and treating swallowing disorders (dysphagia). They can assess the patient's swallowing mechanism, identify the cause of the difficulty, and recommend strategies to improve swallowing safety and efficiency. The 'wet voice' is a key cue.

answerBreakdown.text: Impaired fine motor skills and grip strength in right hand
answerBreakdown.rationale: Occupational therapists focus on improving fine motor skills and hand function, enabling patients to perform activities of daily living. They can provide exercises and adaptive equipment to enhance the patient's ability to manipulate objects and perform tasks like eating and writing.

answerBreakdown.text: Slurred speech and difficulty finding words
answerBreakdown.rationale: Speech therapists are trained to assess and treat speech and language disorders, including dysarthria (slurred speech) and aphasia (difficulty finding words). They can help the patient improve articulation, language comprehension, and communication skills.

Physical therapists specialize in improving mobility, balance, and gait. They can assess the patient's balance and gait, identify the underlying causes of the instability, and provide exercises and assistive devices to improve mobility and reduce the risk of falls.

answerBreakdown.text: Increasing social isolation and feelings of hopelessness
answerBreakdown.rationale: Social workers address the psychosocial needs of patients and their families. They can provide counseling, support, and resources to help patients cope with social isolation, depression, and adjustment to illness and hospitalization. They are key in connecting patients with community resources and support systems.

clinicalPearls: Consider the patient's overall presentation and functional limitations when determining the most appropriate referrals.
Interdisciplinary collaboration is essential for providing holistic patient care.
Early referral to the appropriate specialists can improve patient outcomes and quality of life.

questionTrap.trap: Students may confuse the roles of different therapists, especially occupational and physical therapists.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Emphasize the distinction between fine motor skills (OT) and gross motor skills/mobility (PT). Review the specific areas of expertise for each discipline.

mnemonic.title: SPOT
mnemonic.expansion: Speech, Physical, Occupational Therapists: Remember the areas they focus on to make the right referral.
